title: 104_hr2727
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" aims to ensure that Federal regulations are only enacted by Congress as outlined in Article I of the Constitution. This Act prevents the delegation of regulatory power to unelected officials and requires regulations to be approved by Congress before taking effect, promoting accountability and democracy. SEC. 3. ENACTMENT OF AGENCY REGULATIONS. Regulations cannot take effect before the enactment of a bill containing the regulation's text. Agencies must submit a report to Congress with the regulation's text and an explanation of its basis and purpose. SEC. 4. EXPEDITED CONGRESSIONAL PROCEDURES FOR AGENCY REGULATIONS. (a) Introduction.--Within three legislative days of an agency submitting a report under section 3(b), the Majority Leader of each House of Congress must introduce a bill containing the regulation's text. If the bill is not introduced, any Member of that House may do so.
(b) Bill.--A bill under this section refers to a bill in Congress that approves agency regulations, with the regulations' text included.
(c) Referral and Consideration.--The bill described in subsection (b) does not need to be referred to a committee, and any Member of the respective House can move for consideration. (c) Referral and Consideration.--A bill described in subsection (b) does not require committee referral. Any Member of the respective House can move for consideration the day after announcing their intention. All points of order are waived, and the motion is privileged, not debatable, and not subject to amendment. The motion on the bill is not amendable, subject to postponement, or consideration of other business. Reconsidering the vote on the motion is not allowed. Debate on the bill is limited to one hour, with equal time for supporters and opponents. Amendments are not permitted, but a motion to further limit debate is allowed. Final passage of a bill must occur within 60 days of its introduction in a House of Congress. Appeals on procedural decisions are made without debate. Final passage of a bill in Congress must occur within 60 days of its introduction. A motion to suspend certain subsections is allowed and can be passed with a majority vote. If the other House receives a bill with the same text, it cannot be considered except for final passage. Upon disposition of a bill received from the other House, it shall no longer be in order to consider the bill that originated in the receiving House. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "agency" and "regulation" in accordance with existing laws. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act applies to agency regulations made after its enactment. SEC. 7. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Regulations in bills from this Act are not subject to judicial review as agency actions.
